text: we were basically each other's grief
counselors and we were sort of figuring
out what are our lives priorities now
what what's important bill and I both
lost our respective spouses in 2010 my
husband died very rapidly over about
three and a half months and Bill's wife
was sick for four years dating at 52
after decades of being married to one
person in a very happy marriage it was
frightening I spent so much time wanting
to get my life back to normal but I was
so fearful that things were going to
turn out badly that I expected him to
turn out badly and all of a sudden she
comes walking across Fifth Avenue and I
look at her and it's like the whole city
lit up I don't recall what we ate or
even what we talked about but the thing
that I really took to heart was as we
were saying goodbye the concept of next
came up well try and do something next
or somehow I left with the feeling that
that there would be a next time and that
was the most uplifting most emotive
edifice so
one of the things that I decided I
needed to do as my husband dime was
instead of being sad and kind of going
into myself that I might learn to do
something new bill is a really good
cyclist and he taught me how to ride a
bicycle and I said why don't we get a
tandem and I wrote on the back and
learned all about cadence and balance
and whatnot and we put our departed
spouses initials on it and the date and
we rode that bike all over the place the
first year or so bad things happened
very quickly and there's no it's just
the worst thing you can do is waste
another day absolutely life is for
living I think you can have two love's
in your life I certainly have
I don't know whether somebody helped me
get to end or whether it was at my own
good fortune or freewill and I want a
merrier I mean it's pure and simple it's
totally selfish I don't have to justify
it because others want me to marry her I
want to marry her and I want to do this
for myself
and we are
